text:
NO
A 60-year-old adult being managed by a developmental pediatrician is unrealistic because pediatric subspecialists do not ordinarily provide ongoing care for older adults.

A 25-year-old man with metastatic prostate cancer is being evaluated with whole exome sequencing (WES) after a chromosomal microarray (CMA) was non-diagnostic; the test was ordered by his obstetrician, he has not undergone pre-test genetic counseling, and his reported family history includes a sibling with global developmental delay, with coverage through Cigna.

A 12-year-old is undergoing evaluation for dysmorphic facial features and whole exome sequencing (WES) has been ordered by a gynecologist after prior karyotype testing was non-diagnostic; the family history is notable for a mother with autism spectrum disorder, the patient is insured by Cigna, and pre-test genetic counseling was offered but declined.

NO
The requested testing is for prostate cancer risk/management, which is an adult-only clinical indication and is inconsistent with the patient’s age of 9 years.

NO
A 5-week-old infant cannot have a personal history of exocrine pancreatic cancer, which is an adult-onset diagnosis incompatible with the neonatal age.

NO
Multiple congenital anomalies are a pediatric presentation and thus are inconsistent with a 72-year-old patient.

A 2-year-old child with unexplained epileptic encephalopathy with onset before age three, and no prior epilepsy multigene panel testing, is being evaluated by a neonatologist who has ordered whole exome sequencing (WES) with coverage through Cigna; prior FISH testing was performed and was non-diagnostic, no pre-test genetic counseling has been conducted, and there is a family history of breast cancer in the mother diagnosed at or before age 50.

A 14-year-old with multiple congenital anomalies not consistent with a well-delineated genetic syndrome is being referred for chromosomal microarray analysis for developmental disorders (CMA) after a prior chromosomal microarray (CMA) was non-diagnostic; the ordering provider is a Family Medicine Physician and the patient has seen a genetic counselor multiple times. The family history is notable for three relatives with breast cancer — the patient's mother, maternal grandmother, and a maternal aunt. Insurance for testing is BCBS_FEP.

NO
Meconium ileus is a neonatal condition presenting at or shortly after birth and cannot plausibly be the indication for testing in an 18-year-old.

NO
The clinical indication is for invasive prenatal testing but the listed patient is 69 years old, which is incompatible with a prenatal/fetal context.

A 64-year-old individual with longstanding dysmorphic features is being evaluated with a chromosomal microarray (CMA) to assess for an underlying developmental disorder; there has been no prior genetic testing, and the family history is notable for a brother who was diagnosed with moderate-to-severe intellectual disability by age 18. The test was ordered by a nurse practitioner, insurance coverage is through Cigna, and there is no documentation of pretest genetic counseling.

The patient is a 3-year-old with congenital coloboma, and because of a sibling with moderate-to-severe intellectual disability diagnosed by age 18, the Family Medicine Physician has ordered chromosomal microarray analysis for developmental disorders; there has been no prior genetic testing, the family declined pre-test genetic counseling, and the testing will be billed to Cigna.

A 10-year-old child is being evaluated for a history of abnormal muscle tone dating back to infancy, described as episodes of hypotonia or hypertonia, and chromosomal microarray testing for developmental disorders is being pursued; prior FISH testing was performed and was non-diagnostic. The family history is notable for a sibling who had a brief resolved unexplained event characterized by altered responsiveness, cyanosis, pallor, and irregular breathing. The evaluation was ordered by a Family Medicine Physician, genetic counseling has not been conducted, and insurance coverage is through BCBS_FEP.

A 2-year-old child is being evaluated for a major congenital or developmental abnormality affecting at least one organ system, and whole exome sequencing (WES) has been ordered by the neurologist after karyotype testing was non-diagnostic; the family reports that the child's mother had triple-negative breast cancer, and the family’s insurance is Cigna.

A 63-year-old patient with unexplained epileptic encephalopathy that began before age three is being evaluated by a cardiologist who ordered BRCA1/2 testing; no prior epilepsy multigene panel testing has been performed, prior karyotype testing was non-diagnostic, a sibling is reported to have consanguinity in the family, the patient has seen a genetic counselor multiple times for pre-test counseling, and insurance is BCBS_FEP.

The patient is a 5-year-old who presents with moderate-to-severe intellectual disability and is undergoing chromosomal microarray analysis for developmental disorders after prior karyotype testing was non-diagnostic; the test was ordered by an oncologist, the family reports an uncle with pancreatic cancer, the patient is insured through BCBS_FEP, and a genetic counselor was seen prior to testing with a follow-up visit planned to review results.

NO
Testing a 13-week gestation fetus for adult‑onset cancer susceptibility genes such as BRCA1/2 is unrealistic because prenatal testing for fetal structural anomalies should be limited to karyotype, chromosomal microarray, or fetal exome/genome rather than adult-onset cancer gene panels.

At 15 weeks' gestation, a fetus with multiple congenital anomalies is being evaluated with chromosomal microarray analysis after karyotype testing was non‑diagnostic; the mother has a history of short stature, the study was ordered by a cardiologist, the family is insured through UHC, and a genetic counselor saw the family before testing and will review results afterward.

A 10-year-old child is being evaluated for developmental delay and intellectual disability without features suggestive of a specific syndrome, and there is a reported sibling with a congenital anomaly; prior constitutional chromosomal microarray analysis (CMA) was non-diagnostic. The ordering provider is a neonatologist who has requested a tumor-directed chromosomal microarray (CMA_tumor), no pre-test genetic counseling was conducted, and the family’s insurance is BCBS_FEP.

NO
The indication describes a prenatal fetus with multiple structural anomalies but the record lists the patient as 75 years old; prenatal/fetal cases are valid only when age_years == -1, so this scenario is inconsistent.

A 40-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer diagnosed at age 40 is being evaluated, and her cardiologist has ordered chromosomal microarray analysis (CMA) intended for developmental disorder assessment; prior FISH testing was non-diagnostic, her father has a history of metastatic prostate cancer, and she is insured through UHC.

A 51-year-old patient is being evaluated for pancreatic cancer and a medical geneticist has ordered chromosomal microarray analysis (CMA) under BCBS_FEP; there is a reported family history of a brother with a growth abnormality, no prior genetic testing has been performed, and no genetic counseling has been conducted.

A 2-year-old child is being evaluated for a persistent, severe immunologic or hematologic disorder, and whole genome sequencing (WGS) has been ordered by a General Practitioner after Fragile X testing was non-diagnostic; there is a family history of the mother having breast cancer diagnosed at age 50 or younger, and the patient’s insurance is BCBS_FEP.

The patient is a 6-week-old infant with a major abnormality affecting at least one organ system who is being evaluated with tumor chromosomal microarray analysis after a prior chromosomal microarray (CMA) was non-diagnostic; the test was ordered by the neurologist, the family declined pre-test genetic counseling, there is a family history of arrhythmia in the father, and the evaluation will be billed to UHC.

A 42-year-old patient is being evaluated for a history of abnormal muscle tone in infancy, described as hypotonia or hypertonia, and BRCA1/2 testing has been ordered despite the neonatal-onset symptom; Fragile X testing was previously performed and was non-diagnostic. The patient reports a sibling with a growth abnormality such as short stature, the test was ordered by a General Practitioner, no genetic counseling has been conducted to date, and the testing will be submitted to UHC.

An 8-year-old patient with reported parental consanguinity was evaluated by a Medical Geneticist after a sibling was noted to have a persistent, severe immunologic or hematologic disorder; prior FISH testing was non-diagnostic, and following discussion with a genetic specialist the Medical Geneticist ordered chromosomal microarray analysis on tumor tissue (CMA_tumor) with testing to be billed to BCBS_FEP.

A 5-year-old child with global developmental delay is undergoing evaluation by a pediatric neurologist who has ordered whole genome sequencing (WGS) after a chromosomal microarray (CMA) was non-diagnostic; the family reports a sibling affected by epileptic encephalopathy with onset before age three, they saw a genetic counselor prior to testing and will meet again after results are returned, and coverage is through BCBS_FEP.

The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer diagnosed before age 50 who is being referred for chromosomal microarray analysis (CMA); the order was placed by an obstetrician and the testing and implications were discussed with a genetic specialist. Her sister had ovarian carcinoma, prior CMA testing was non‑diagnostic, and her insurance is UHC.

A 5-week-old infant is being evaluated for a recently identified primary solid tumor with a family history notable for the infant’s father having high‑risk prostate cancer and additional affected relatives on the same side of the family, and the neurologist has ordered chromosomal microarray for developmental disorders to assess for copy‑number variants; prior Fragile X testing was non‑diagnostic, no genetic counselor involvement was documented, and the patient is insured through Cigna.

NO
Breast cancer is an adult-onset condition and is biologically implausible as a clinical indication in a 1-year-old child.

NO
A 68-year-old adult being managed by a general pediatrician is unrealistic.

NO
This is unrealistic because lobular breast cancer and diffuse gastric cancer are adult-onset conditions and it is essentially impossible for a 5-year-old to have lobular breast carcinoma.

At 14 weeks’ gestation, a fetus is being evaluated for a major structural congenital abnormality affecting at least one organ system and chromosomal microarray analysis (CMA) has been requested after prior FISH testing was non-diagnostic; the pregnancy is managed by a gynecologist, the patient declined genetic counseling, and there is a family history notable for breast cancer in a paternal uncle who was assigned male at birth, with testing to be billed through UHC.

NO
BRCA1/2 testing is inappropriate for a 24-week gestation fetus because prenatal testing should not be used to assess adult-onset cancer susceptibility genes.

The patient is a 4-year-old with abnormal muscle tone that began in infancy and is being evaluated for persistent hypotonia/hypertonia, and chromosomal microarray (CMA) testing is being requested by a Medical Geneticist; prior FISH testing was non-diagnostic. There is a family history of autism spectrum disorder in a sibling, the case was discussed with a genetic specialist, and the patient’s insurance is Cigna.

NO
Developmental delay is a pediatric-onset indication and is unrealistic in a clearly adult (68-year-old) patient.

A 13-year-old adolescent with Hirschsprung disease is undergoing BRCA1/2 testing ordered by an obstetrician despite no prior genetic testing; the patient has a sibling who was diagnosed with moderate intellectual disability by age 18, a genetic counselor saw the patient before testing and will provide follow-up when results are available, and testing will be billed to BCBS_FEP.

The 71-year-old patient has a lifelong history of global developmental delay and is being evaluated for chromosomal abnormalities; the Family Medicine Physician has ordered a tumor chromosomal microarray (CMA_tumor) after prior karyotype testing was non-diagnostic, the patient has a brother with breast cancer, the case was discussed with a genetic specialist, and the patient’s insurance is UHC.

An 11-year-old is being evaluated for multiple congenital anomalies by a neurologist; there has been no prior genetic testing, and the family reports a sibling with global developmental delay, so the neurologist has ordered whole exome sequencing (WES) through BCBS_FEP, and the family declined pre-test genetic counseling.

A 9-year-old patient is undergoing chromosomal microarray analysis (CMA) to evaluate an epithelial ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal cancer diagnosis, and prior karyotype testing was non-diagnostic; the case is being managed by a developmental pediatrician, a genetic counselor was seen prior to testing and will be seen again after results are received, there is a reported history of consanguinity in a parent, and testing will be billed to UHC.

The patient is a 4-year-old being evaluated for a complex movement disorder characterized predominantly by dystonia and ataxia with intermittent hemiplegic episodes; a developmental pediatrician has ordered a tumor chromosomal microarray (CMA_tumor) after a prior constitutional chromosomal microarray (CMA) was non-diagnostic, the family reports that the mother had triple-negative breast cancer, genetic counseling was declined, and testing will be submitted to UHC.

The patient is a 19-year-old with a congenital structural anomaly who is being evaluated with tumor chromosomal microarray analysis after a prior constitutional chromosomal microarray (CMA) was non-diagnostic; the test was ordered by an obstetrician, the patient has seen a genetic counselor multiple times, coverage is through Cigna, and family history is notable for an aunt with two or more cancers consistent with Lynch syndrome.

A 4-week-old infant is being evaluated for multiple congenital anomalies without features of a well-defined genetic syndrome, and a developmental pediatrician has ordered BRCA1/2 testing despite no prior genetic testing; the family history is notable for a father who died suddenly before age 35, and the patient’s insurance is UHC.

A 48-year-old patient with autism spectrum disorder is being evaluated by an oncologist and referred for BRCA1/2 testing because the patient's mother had triple-negative breast cancer; prior karyotype testing was non-diagnostic, no pre-test genetic counseling has been conducted, and the patient carries UHC insurance.

A 7-week-old infant is being evaluated for abnormal muscle tone presenting as hypotonia; there is a sibling with a history of developmental delay, and no prior genetic testing has been performed. The Gynecologist has ordered chromosomal microarray analysis for developmental disorders (CMA) to investigate possible genomic causes. No pre-test genetic counseling has been conducted. The patient is insured through UHC.

A 62-year-old patient is being evaluated for persistent seizures, and the primary care physician has ordered whole exome sequencing (WES) to investigate a possible genetic cause; prior FISH testing was non-diagnostic, the patient reports that their mother had two different primary solid tumors, the patient declined genetic counseling prior to testing, and the patient's insurance is Cigna.

The 69-year-old patient is being evaluated for lifelong dysmorphic features and a chromosomal microarray (CMA) has been ordered by a Medical Geneticist for genomic copy-number assessment; the patient reports a son with an inborn error of metabolism, has had no prior genetic testing, and declined pre-test genetic counseling, and insurance is through Cigna.

A 24-year-old patient is being evaluated for significant hypotonia, and an obstetrician has ordered whole genome sequencing after prior karyotype testing was non-diagnostic; the family history is notable for sudden unexplained death of a sibling before age 35, pre-test discussion was held with a genetic specialist, and the testing is to be billed to BCBS_FEP.

NO
BRUE (brief resolved unexplained event) is an infant-only diagnosis and is not compatible with a 54-year-old patient.

An 18-year-old is being evaluated for progressive, unexplained developmental regression not attributable to autism spectrum disorder or epilepsy; prior chromosomal microarray analysis (CMA) was non-diagnostic and whole genome sequencing (WGS) has been requested to seek an underlying genetic cause. The ordering provider is a neonatologist, and the patient has seen a genetic counselor multiple times for pre-test counseling. Family history is notable for an uncle with pancreatic cancer, and the patient’s insurance is Cigna.
